奥迪的 DTM 计划——就像德国的 NASCAR 一样——在 2020 年底结束，2021 年是这家德国汽车制造商在电动方程式中的最后一年。但奥迪运动在这两个项目中的投资不会白费，因为每台机器都组合在一起，为一台外观令人发指的机器提供动力，该机器旨在参加达喀尔拉力赛。今天在网上发布，这款车被称为奥迪 RS Q e-tron，奥迪表示，在世界上最艰难的越野比赛之一中进行竞选将使该公司能够“在极端条件下”测试和开发其电动动力系统。尽管在过去的几十年里，奥迪的赛车运动主要发生在赛道的范围内，但该品牌与拉力赛有着密切的联系。它利用 1980 年代的世界拉力锦标赛来展示其 quattro 全轮驱动技术。它们可能都涉及拉力赛，但达喀尔比 WRC 更具挑战性，因为它在偏远地区进行了为期两周的比赛，每天的距离为 500 英里（800 公里）。 “这是一个很长的距离，”奥迪运动达喀尔项目负责人 Andreas Roos 说。 “我们尝试做的事情以前从未有人做过。这是电动传动系统的终极挑战。”达喀尔的性质排除了纯粹的电池电动方法，尽管过去曾尝试过这种方法。相反，奥迪运动采用了系列混合动力方法——是的，系列混合动力车迷，我们认为这个方法通过了纯度测试。管架式 RS Q e-tron 使用来自 Audi Sport 当前电动方程式计划的一对 250 kW (335 hp) 电动机/发电机组 (MGU)，每个轴上安装一个。这些由 52 kWh（可用）锂离子电池组供电，该电池组可能是从奥迪 e-tron FE07 电动方程式赛车中借来的。总输出功率为 500 千瓦（670 马力）。然后是第三个 Formula E MGU，它是能量转换器的一部分，在 RS Q e-tron 行驶时为电池充电。 （两个推进 MGU 还将在制动时再生能量。）能量转换器的另一个组件是来自 Audi Sport 的 DTM 汽车的 2.0 L TSFI 发动机，它通过轴连接到第三个 MGU。您可能不会期望高度串联的赛车发动机可以作为发电机很好地工作，但奥迪运动表示，在正确的转速范围内，发动机实际上是高效的。 “我们将输出功率从 450 kW 降低到约 200 kW。它在 4,500 到 6,000 rpm 之间的狭窄优化转速范围内运行，而不是 9,000 rpm，”奥迪运动赛车项目开发负责人 Stefan Dreyer 说。 “发动机必须在炎热、寒冷和高海拔地区尽可能高效地运行。我们为此优化了活塞、喷油器和涡轮增压器，并在测试台上花费了大量时间。我们为特定消耗量感到自豪远低于每千瓦时 200 克。”
“传动系统非常高效。几乎没有任何功率损失。当你在沙地上缓慢行驶时，你不必担心温度问题。但最重要的是，在所有给定的情况下，电动传动系统更容易控制情况，”德雷尔说。 “从零转即可获得最大扭矩。您可以非常精确地调节动力传动系统，无论汽车是跳跃还是在沙漠中行驶。电动动力传动系统不会对气压、温度和湿度等外部影响做出反应。你可以在整个拉力赛中全功率使用它。它比内燃机更稳定。” RS Q e-tron 也将每晚充电。尽管奥迪运动还没有展示充电解决方案，但它表示计划使用尽可能多的清洁能源。并且这辆车的设计目的是由一个小型支持团队提供高度的维修服务。原型 RS Q e-tron 于 7 月初首次亮相，现在它正在接受今年剩余时间的广泛测试计划，然后是明年 1 月在沙特阿拉伯举行的 2022 年达喀尔拉力赛。奥迪运动将参加 Q Motorsport 运营的三辆 RS Q e-tron。 Mattias Ekström（为奥迪赢得 DTM 和 Rallycross 锦标赛冠军）和 Emil Bergkvist 将共享一辆赛车，一辆由 14 次达喀尔冠军 Stéphane Peterhansel 和 Edouard Boulanger 共享，第三辆由 Carlos Sainz（WRC 两项冠军和三项冠军）共享。时间达喀尔冠军）和卢卡斯克鲁兹。
title: 奥迪 RS Q e-tron 结合了三台电动方程式发动机和一台 DTM 发动机
title_en: Three Formula E motors and a DTM engine combine in the Audi RS Q e-tron

note: Apple 的 Pro Display XDR 已经上市有一段时间了，但目前还没有关于其高价显示器更新版本的传言。然而，9to5Mac 现在从熟悉此事的消息人士那里获悉，苹果正在内部测试一款带有专用 A13 芯片和神经引擎的新外部显示器。新显示器的开发代号为 J327，但目前尚不清楚有关技术规格的详细信息。据消息人士透露，这款显示器将配备苹果制造的 SoC，目前是 A13 仿生芯片——与 iPhone 11 系列中使用的芯片相同。与 A13 芯片一起，外部显示器具有神经引擎，可加速机器学习任务。尽管有传言称苹果一直在为普通用户开发更便宜的显示器，但带有专用 SoC 的新外部显示器将来很可能会成为替代当前 Pro Display XDR 的新型号。早在 2016 年，就在 Apple 的 Thunderbolt Display 停产之后，有传言称 Apple 正在研究更换高分辨率显示器和内置 GPU。虽然该公司确实在 2019 年推出了自己的高级外接显示器，但 Pro Display XDR 并没有像传言那样配备 GPU。今天来自 9to5Mac 的消息来源的报告表明，苹果并没有放弃其推出带有某种 SoC 的外部显示器的计划，至少在内部是这样。在外部显示器中内置 CPU/GPU 可以帮助 Mac 提供高分辨率图形，而无需使用计算机内部芯片的所有资源。 Apple 还可以将显示 SoC 的强大功能与 Mac 的 SoC 结合起来，为运行密集的图形任务提供更高的性能。请记住，Apple 的计划可能会发生变化，就像第一款 Pro Display XDR 从未拥有传闻中的所有功能一样。苹果对这款新外置显示器的发布计划也不得而知。您正在阅读 9to5Mac — 日复一日地发布有关 Apple 及其周边生态系统新闻的专家。请务必查看我们的主页以获取所有最新消息，并在 Twitter、Facebook 和 LinkedIn 上关注 9to5Mac 以了解最新消息。不知道从哪里开始？查看我们的独家故事、评论、操作方法，并订阅我们的 YouTube 频道
note_en:
Apple’s  Pro Display XDR has been available for quite some time now, but there are still no rumors about an updated version of its high-priced display in the near term. However,  9to5Mac has now learned from sources familiar with the matter that Apple is internally testing a new external display with a dedicated A13 chip and also Neural Engine.
  The new display is being developed under the codename J327, but at this point, details about technical specifications are unclear. According to sources, this display will have an Apple-made SoC, which right now is the A13 Bionic chip — the same one used in the iPhone 11 lineup.
 Along with the A13 chip, the external display features the Neural Engine, which accelerates machine learning tasks. Although rumors suggest that Apple has been working on a  less expensive display for regular users, the new external display with a dedicated SoC will likely be a new model to replace the current Pro Display XDR in the future.
 Back in 2016, right after Apple’s Thunderbolt Display was discontinued,  rumors suggested that Apple was working on a replacement with a high-resolution display and a built-in GPU. While the company has indeed launched its own premium external display in 2019, Pro Display XDR does not come with a GPU as rumors predicted.
 Today’s report from  9to5Mac’s sources suggests that Apple has not given up on its plans to launch an external display with some sort of SoC, at least internally. Having a CPU/GPU built into the external display could help Macs deliver high-resolution graphics without using all the resources of the computer’s internal chip. Apple could also combine the power of the display SoC with the Mac’s SoC to provide even more performance for running intensive graphic tasks.
 Keep in mind that Apple’s plans may change, just as the first Pro Display XDR never had all the features it was rumored to have. Apple’s launch plans for this new external display are also unknown.
  You’re reading 9to5Mac — experts who break news about Apple and its surrounding ecosystem, day after day. 不时有刚毕业的黑客问我：“你对我的职业生涯有什么建议吗？”我发现自己一遍又一遍地重复着 3 条原则。经过反思，我意识到这些原则适用范围更广。我想他们可能会回答这个问题“你对我成年后的生活有什么建议吗？”我想我会在这里与你分享这些想法。我写的风格和例子都是面向职业的，但我认为核心思想仍然有助于你的决策。我希望你喜欢它们 ： ）。你该怎么办？是您刚开始时最难回答的问题之一。默认路径是遵循流行的或有声望的。这可能会导致一系列问题：有声望的东西已经非常具有竞争力。当你在一个既定规则的游戏中与聪明人竞争时，只是跟上节奏会占用你大部分时间。这几乎没有时间去探索你感兴趣的东西。当你不去探索你感兴趣的东西时，你就不会那么深入地理解事物，这给你留下了无差别的技能组合。这里的解决方案是跟随你的口味。人气和声望是滞后指标。你的品味，尤其是作为一个年轻、好奇的人，预示着未来会流行什么。无论如何，当您按照自己的喜好进行操作时，您会发现自己对正在解决的问题更感兴趣。当您对正在解决的问题感兴趣时，您会发现更深层次的真相，积累更深层次的专业知识，形成差异化的技能组合，并在此过程中获得更多乐趣。现在，您可能想知道：如果您甚至不知道自己对什么感兴趣怎么办？
别担心。你只需要调整和加强你的品味。要做到这一点，只要做任何事情。一旦你做了任何事情，问问自己，你觉得这件事的哪一部分有趣？开始深入那里，突然之间，你会发现很多兴趣。别担心。完全没问题。只要跟着它。你会惊讶于事情会如何为你服务。只要你努力工作并且你在学习，这是一个很好的时间利用。您可能还想知道：如果您的兴趣是当今流行和有声望的，该怎么办？那太棒了。遵循这一点，而不是竞争，开始感受你在该领域真正感兴趣的东西，并深入研究。这些想法可能看起来以职业为导向，所以您可能想知道：如果我只想旅行和探索世界怎么办？那也太棒了！这是你的品味，告诉你你想旅行。跟随它，看看它会把你引向何方。
当您发现自己的兴趣时，您可能会发现它们不一定受欢迎。然而，当你更深入地做自己的事情时，会发生一些神奇的事情……这将我们引向第二个原则：当你探索和追随你的品味时，你会发现一部分人与你的核心兴趣和价值观有共同之处。培养这些关系。其中一些人将成为您的终生朋友。这些人中的许多人将来会变得非常成功。您认识的人会向您展示什么是可能的，并与您一起深化、探索和创新您的共同兴趣。您可能想知道：如果您住在偏僻的地方，而且没有人找到您怎么办？尽最大努力去你所在社区的中心。对于黑客来说可能是科幻小说，对于艺人来说可能是洛杉矶，对于艺术家来说可能是巴黎，不胜枚举。你知道它适合你。现在，这对您来说可能听起来不切实际，但您会对自己的能力感到惊讶。在此期间，您可以从网上开始。这里的一个常见陷阱是只关注您所在领域的成功人士。这没有抓住重点。当然，接触那些成功的人，但请记住，你身边的年轻、好奇、感兴趣的人，将来会成为那些成功的人。你们有很多时间在一起度过，所以这是加深你们关系的好方法。我并不是说你不应该接触成功的人（你绝对应该），而是要完全取消“成功”作为选择与谁共度时光的标准。
现在，您可能想知道，您如何加深这些关系？这引出了我们的第三个原则：当你组建你的社区时，新的想法和合作方式就会涌现。抓住这些机会：一起工作、互相支持和玩耍。随着时间的推移，你现在拥有很多，你会形成一个紧密的朋友部落。作为一个快乐的副作用，你会接触到新领域、新技术、有趣的问题和有趣的机会。开始使用它们，您就可以顺利踏上适合您的职业生涯。这里的一个常见问题是缺乏自信。这可能会导致你选择你认为“你有能力”的东西，而不是你感兴趣的东西。解决这个问题的一种方法是尝试：让自己梦想并与朋友一起工作，即使问题看起来非常困难。如果您对我感兴趣的内容感兴趣，我可以举很多例子：从我最喜欢的书到 Paul Graham 的论文，再到 Norvig 的 AI 编程范式，再到 Rich Hickey 的演讲。但是，相反，我鼓励您思考：您现在对​​什么感兴趣？如果你愿意，我很想知道你的答案：你现在对什么感兴趣？随时在评论中留下您的答案或直接给我发电子邮件，我很想知道 :) 有很多人影响和指导了我。这些想法和我一样。
特别是关于品味的想法，保罗格雷厄姆必须大喊大叫。我对这个问题的很多想法都是从我开始时一遍又一遍地阅读他的文章中得到启发的。我强烈建议阅读它们。感谢 Daniel Woelfel、Talha Baig、Martin Raison、Irakli Safareli、David Magaltadze、Joe Averbukh、Julien Odent 对本文的审阅
note_en:
From time to time newly graduated hackers ask me:  “Do you have any advice for beginning my career?”
 I’ve found myself repeating 3 principles over and over again. On reflection, I realized these principles apply more broadly. I  think they might answer the question  “Do you have any advice on for beginning my life as an adult?”
 I thought I’d share these ideas with you here. The style and the examples I wrote are career-oriented, but I think the core ideas will still help in your decision making. I hope you enjoy them : ).
  What should you do? is one of the hardest questions to answer when you start out.
 The default path is to follow what’s popular or prestigious. That can lead to a bunch of problems: What’s prestigious is already highly competitive. When you compete with smart people in a game that has established rules, just keeping up will take most of your time. That leaves little time to explore what interests you. When you don’t explore what interests you, you won’t understand things as deeply, and that leaves you with an undifferentiated skillset.
 The solution here is to follow your taste. Popularity and prestige are lagging indicators. Your taste, especially as a young, curious person, is a signal for  what will be popular in the future. Regardless though, when you follow you taste, you’ll find yourself much more interested in the problems you’re solving. When you’re interested in the problems you’re solving, you’ll discover deeper truths, build deeper expertise, a differentiated skillset, and have more fun along the way.
 Now, you may be wondering:  What if you don’t even know what you’re interested in?
 Don’t worry. You just need to tune into and strengthen your taste. To do that, just do  anything. Once you do  anything, ask yourself, what part of that thing do you find interesting?
 Start going deeper there, and all of a sudden, you’ll discover a wealth of interests.
  Don’t worry. It’s totally fine. Just follow it. You’ll be surprised how things will serve you down the road. As long as you’re working hard and you’re learning, it’s a good use of time.
 You may also wonder:  What if your interests  are what’s popular and prestigious today?
 That’s great. Follow that, but instead of competing, start sensing what actually interests you in that field and go deeper.
 The ideas may seem career oriented, so you may be wondering:  What if I just want to travel and explore the world?
 That’s great too! It’s your taste, telling you that you want to travel. Follow it and see where it leads you.
 As you discover your interests, you may find that they’re not necessarily popular. Yet, when you go deeper and do your thing, something magical will happen…which leads us into the second principle:
  As you explore and follow your taste, you’ll discover a subset of people who share your core interests and values.
 Nurture those relationships. Some of these people will be your friends for life. Many of those people will become very successful in the future.
 The people you know will show you what’s possible and work alongside you in deepening, exploring, and innovating on your shared interests.
 You may be wondering:  what if you live in the middle of nowhere, and there aren’t people who get you? Do your best to go to the center of wherever your community is. That may be SF for hackers or Los Angeles for entertainers or Paris for artists, the list goes on. You know where it is for you.
 Now, this may sound impractical to you, but you’ll be surprised with what you can do. You can start off online in the meantime.
 One common pitfall here is  focusing only on successful people in your field. This misses the point. Sure, reach out to those successful people, but remember that the young, curious, interested people right next you,  will become those successful people in the future. You have tons of time to spend together, so it’s great way to deepen your relationships. I’m not saying that you shouldn’t reach out to successful people (you definitely should), but to remove “success” as a criteria altogether for choosing who you spend your time with.
 Now, you may be wondering,  how do you deepen those relationships? That leads to us to the third principle:
  As you form your community, new ideas and ways to collaborate will spring up. Take those opportunities: work together, support each-other and play. Over time, which you have a lot of right now, you will form a tight tribe of friends.
 As a happy side effect, you’ll become exposed to new fields, new technologies, interesting problems, and interesting opportunities. Start taking them, and you’re well on your way to a career that’s  made for you.
 One common issue here is a lack of self belief. This may lead you into choosing what you think “you are capable of”, rather than what you’re interested in. One way to get around this is to just experiment: let yourself dream and work with your friends, even if the problems seem fantastically hard.
  There are a lot of examples I can give you if you’re interested in what I’m interesting in: From  my favorite books to  Paul Graham’s essays to  Norvig’s Paradgims of AI programming, to  Rich Hickey talks. But, instead I encourage you to think:  what interests you right now?
 If you’re up for it, I’d love to know your answer:   what interests you right now? Feel free to leave your answer in the comments or to email me directly, I’d be curious to hear : )
  There’s a slew of people who have influenced and mentored me. These ideas are just as much them as me.
 On the idea of taste specifically, the big shoutout has to go to Paul Graham. A lot of my thinking about this was inspired by reading his essays over and over when I started out. I highly suggest reading them.
 Thanks to Daniel Woelfel, Talha Baig, Martin Raison, Irakli Safareli, David Magaltadze, Joe Averbukh, Julien Odent, for reviewing this essay

Web 的第一个浏览器具有全彩色、读/写功能和多个窗口。第二个浏览器是一个纯文本的命令行工具。猜猜人们实际使用的是哪一种？在 Web 出现之前，Gopher 提供了一种连接到 Internet 和共享文档的方法。如果情况有所不同，它甚至可能成为我们今天用来浏览信息的方式。有没有想过人们是如何发现网络的。它存在的第一个传输是数字传输，一个 Usenet 帖子，引发了早期网络先驱的追随。没有超文本，就没有万维网。但它的名称和概念早于网络的诞生几十年。 Tim Berners-Lee 曾多次表示，美国的第一个网站是网络起飞的主要原因之一。但是它做了什么，为什么它如此重要？ 《王冠》第二季有这个场景（如果你看足够多的老电影，你会看到同样的类型[…]为什么是<img>标签而不是<image>标签？答案，原来如此，可以追溯到网络最早的浏览器之一和网络最早的讨论之一。
信不信由你，搜索引擎之前曾有过一段时间。在网络上发现要困难得多。很容易迷路。也就是说，直到几个不同的人创建了一张地图。上次我回顾了 WWW Wizards Workshop 的重要性 [...] 在浏览器真正跨平台之前，曾经有一段时间每个操作系统都有自己选择的浏览器，并且它是为这些用户的需求。在 1995 年，很难相信您可以从网上冲浪中赢得 100 万美元。然后，AOL 使之成为可能。主页这个词在 90 年代中后期开始流行，但它的起源可以追溯到网络的开始。有每个人都听说过的浏览器。还有一些，无论出于何种原因，都消失了。这些是后者。感谢网络，在 1999 年（或左右），您可能会发现自己在家，盯着电脑屏幕的虚拟窗口，看着您最喜欢的网吧的真实窗口。
网络分布访问、信息访问和相互访问。网络访问将我们带到斐济海岸附近的小岛，网络先驱在那里建立了一个独特的社区。这是有史以来第一个弹出式广告的创建者的消息：现在很明显，我们所做的是一个 [...] Geocities 很可能是您听说过的网站。它甚至可能是您使用过的网站。它的起源，以及它后来激发的运动，是一个关于自我表达和机缘巧合的令人难以置信的故事。
note_en:
The web’s first browser featured full color, read/write capabilities, and multiple windows. The second browser was a text-only command line tool. Guess which one people actually used?
    Before the web, Gopher offered a way to connect to the Internet and share documents. And if things had gone a little differently, it might even be what we use to surf information today.
          Ever wondered how people found about the web. The first transmission of its existence was a digital one, a Usenet post that sparked a following of early web pioneers.
      Without hypertext, there would be no World Wide Web. But its name and conception predate the web’s creation by decades.
      Tim Berners-Lee has said, on multiple occasions, the the first website in the US was one of the major reasons the web took off. But what did it do and why was it so important?

                Why is it the <img> tag instead of the <image> tag? The answer, it turns out, dates back to one of the web’s earliest browsers and one of the web’s earliest discussions.
        Believe it or not, there was a time before search engines. Discovery on the web was far more difficult. It was easy to get lost. That is, until a few different people created a map.
    I talked a bit about the importance of the WWW Wizards Workshop last time in my recap on the importance […]
                      Before browsers were truly cross-platform, there was a time when each operating system had their browser of choice, and it was tailored to the needs of those users.
    In 1995, it would be hard to believe that you could win a million dollars from surfing the web. Then, AOL made it possible.
    The word homepage came into popular use in the mid to late 90’s, but it’s origin dates back to the web’s beginning.
      There are the browsers that everyone’s heard of. And then there are some that, for whatever reason, faded away. These are the latter.
        Thanks to the web, in 1999 (or thereabouts), you might find yourself at home, staring at the virtual window of your computer screen, looking out the very real windows of your favorite cyber café.
      The web distributes access, access to information, and access to one another. Access on the web is what brings us to small island off the coast of Fiji, where web pioneers forged a unique community.
